# Contributor Approach
Catalyst's historical funding delays created situations where promised contributor engagement could not be honored, damaging relationships despite good intentions. 



Learning from this, this proposer commits to onboarding computational commons contributors—workshop facilitators, schema architects, cultural consultants building on delegated representatives from over fifty-one countries, translators emphasizing subject-object-verb structures across eight languages, disaster specialists, rural revitalization experts, legal advisors across UK, Swiss, and Japanese contexts, technical writers, community coordinators, partnership liaisons, and video producers—only after funding receipt and stable currency conversion ensuring reliable compensation.



This milestone-threshold approach protects both contributor relationships and project reputation. Should early milestones not achieve objectives as community determines, funding firewall ensures remaining allocations stay secure rather than creating cascading failures. Given eight years visible participation, reputation preservation through honest execution carries paramount importance. 



The approach provides latitude for adapting to emergent realities while maintaining accountability through deliverable-based evaluation, with transparent communication about challenges and good-faith efforts toward objectives.

sub_fields.title: Who you’re targeting, how you’ll reach them, and why this matters for Cardano?
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
We target computational commons contributors across the over fifty-one countries represnted by delegated represntatives who understand that meaningful change emerges from patient collaborative work rather than viral metrics. 



We reach them, in person or otherwise, through intensive workshop processes at Central Saint Martins, University of the Arts London, Tokyo University of the Arts, and Institute of Science Tokyo where depth of engagement matters infinitely more than breadth of passive awareness. 



This matters for Cardano because revolutionary governance frameworks enabling automated systems to operate with genuine human oversight have never emerged from counting attendees or measuring social media impressions. 



Ask yourself: did the development of public key cryptography, the invention of the World Wide Web, or the creation of Bitcoin itself come from optimizing follower counts and event attendance metrics? 



Substance emerges from uncommon approaches pursued by people willing to challenge conventional assumptions about what constitutes progress. We deliberately reject vanity metrics precisely because doing things that don't scale—deep collaboration, cultural adaptation, patient schema development—creates foundations that subsequent scaling can build upon, whereas optimizing for scale from inception produces shallow structures that collapse under complexity.

sub_fields.title: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.description: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.answer:
TLDR

Contributors building technological systems face legal vulnerability without institutional protection, while no organizational form integrates the multidisciplinary expertise automation increasingly requires. As systems become automated, they need governance frameworks that are both machine-readable and human-informed, spanning legal, cultural, technical, and operational domains. Current structures separate these disciplines completely. Sovereigns.institute addresses this through twelve months of international workshops across London and Tokyo where participants from fifty-one countries collaboratively design governance schema before any legal entity forms. These workshops produce machine-readable frameworks for personalised data sovereignty, internationalization enabling cultural diversity, and polymorphic resources representing complex real-world relationships. The UK Charitable Incorporated Organisation with Alternative Business Structure and Donor-Advised Fund capacity represents temporary legal scaffolding, not the destination. These structures are falsework enabling emergence of something more fundamental: governance frameworks that automated systems will inherit and operate within, keeping humans meaningfully in the loop. The workshops validate these frameworks through real-world applications including Japanese disaster management and rural revitalization. What emerges transcends the initial organizational forms—governance that operates at the velocity and granularity automation demands while preserving human judgment across diverse cultural and professional perspectives.

Problem Description

The Protection and Integration Gap

Contributors building technological systems remain personally exposed to legal action without institutional backing. Member-based organizations coordinate development and fund infrastructure but provide zero legal protection when contributors face lawsuits, intellectual property challenges, or jurisdictional conflicts. You contribute expertise and create value yet stand alone if legal pressure emerges. This protection gap intensifies as systems scale toward billions of users where individual contributors become visible targets.

Beyond protection, current organizational structures fundamentally cannot integrate multidisciplinary expertise into unified frameworks. Lawyers work separately from engineers who work separately from cultural specialists who work separately from healthcare practitioners. The UK Alternative Business Structure framework permits non-lawyer domain experts working directly within legal service provision, creating unprecedented integration possibilities, yet no organization serving technological ecosystems has implemented this capability.

The Automation Governance Challenge

As systems become increasingly automated, reliable operation demands more than technical correctness alone. Contextual understanding spanning legal frameworks, cultural norms, ethical considerations, and operational realities becomes essential. Fact patterns—the legally relevant circumstances surrounding events—need systematization into machine-readable formats where humans from diverse backgrounds remain actively involved. This requires organizational structures designed for this integration from inception, not awkwardly retrofitted later when incompatibilities surface.

Traditional Donor-Advised Funds struggle with in-kind donations because monetary valuation systems fail capturing heterogeneous contributions. Technical expertise, cultural knowledge, time-based contributions, and specialized understanding resist translation into simple financial equivalents. Combining DAF capacity with ABS multidisciplinary expertise creates mechanisms for evaluating diverse contributions without depending on monetary pricing that systematically undervalues certain forms of work.

The UK Property Digital Assets Bill creates world-first legal recognition of digital assets as property, but realizing this breakthrough requires organizational structures capable of bridging technical, cultural, legal, and operational domains simultaneously. Recent infrastructure incidents revealed that resilience requires governance mechanisms extending beyond code. Better decision-making with genuine stakeholder participation—actual skin in the game through diverse contribution recognition—reduces attack surfaces by distributing responsibility broadly. When more participants maintain infrastructure through heterogeneous contributions beyond just capital, ecosystems become inherently more resilient.

Solution Architecture

TLDR on the Approach

Twelve months of international workshops across London and Tokyo create governance schema before any legal entity registers. Participants from fifty-one countries collaboratively design machine-readable frameworks that automated systems will eventually inherit and operate within. The organizational forms—UK Charitable Incorporated Organisation as Alternative Business Structure with Donor-Advised Fund capacity—represent temporary legal scaffolding enabling emergence rather than terminal goals. Think of these as falsework in construction: essential temporary structures that support the building process but dissolve once permanent architecture stands independently. What persists beyond the organizational containers are the governance frameworks themselves, operating at the velocity and granularity automation demands while keeping humans meaningfully involved across diverse cultural and professional perspectives.

Sovereigns.institute will operate as UK Charitable Incorporated Organisation registered as Alternative Business Structure with Donor-Advised Fund capacity once workshops complete and community consensus emerges around optimal structure. This combination enables legal service provision with genuine multidisciplinary expertise where cryptographers, engineers, cultural specialists, healthcare practitioners, and educators work directly alongside legal practitioners. The Alternative Business Structure component focuses on systematization rather than litigation—translating fact patterns and legal frameworks into schema that automated systems reference reliably while keeping humans actively in the loop. As automation advances, organizational structures that represent legal knowledge in machine-readable formats while maintaining human oversight from diverse backgrounds become essential infrastructure rather than optional additions.

The Donor-Advised Fund component combined with Alternative Business Structure multidisciplinary expertise creates mechanisms for evaluating and recognizing diverse contributions without forcing everything through monetary pricing. This matters because as automation transforms economic structures, recognizing heterogeneous value forms—time, knowledge, cultural context, specialized expertise—becomes critical for maintaining human participation in governance.

Workshop-Driven Schema Development

Rather than forming entities prematurely and hoping communities eventually shape them, sovereigns.institute inverts this sequence entirely. Twelve months of international workshops happen before any legal registration occurs. Variables discovered through deliberation must settle into understood constants before commitments solidify into organizational structures. This patient approach prioritizes genuine community ownership over expedient entity formation.

London workshops partner with Central Saint Martins and University of the Arts London, leveraging alumni networks to engage interaction designers, anthropologists, legal scholars, healthcare practitioners, and educators concerned about automation-driven displacement. These institutions contribute human-centered design methodology, cultural awareness, and creative problem-solving. Tokyo workshops partner with Tokyo University of the Arts contributing creative and cultural perspectives, and Institute of Science Tokyo bringing technical depth in cryptography, distributed systems, game theory, and soft robotics exploring artificial muscles and biomimetic systems. These partnerships build on pre-existing relationships Central Saint Martins established with both Tokyo universities.

Tokyo applications address disaster management covering earthquakes, tsunamis, typhoons, landslides, volcanic eruptions, and electromagnetic pulses, plus rural revitalization addressing depopulation, aging demographics, agricultural sustainability, cultural preservation, and infrastructure maintenance. Japanese public data initiatives enable developing schema that coordinate heterogeneous resources without forcing monetary equivalence. An elderly resident's traditional agricultural knowledge, a remote worker's technical skills, a municipality's equipment inventory, and external financial support all contribute meaningfully through frameworks recognizing distinct value forms appropriately.

Workshops produce schema in three foundational domains. Personalised data establishes on-device sovereignty ensuring individuals control information about themselves. Internationalization creates universal reference frameworks other schema invoke for language and cultural context, ensuring systems accommodate genuine diversity. Polymorphic resources enable single identifiers representing multiple simultaneous valid interpretations with different permissions, reflecting complex stakeholder relationships reality demands but current systems cannot express. Educational content in eight languages (English, Japanese, Chinese, Tamil, Hindi, Arabic, Malay, Spanish) ensures accessibility across constitutional representatives from fifty-one countries.

These schema represent what persists beyond organizational forms. As automation advances and digital governance systems mature, these machine-readable frameworks continue operating while the legal scaffolding that enabled their creation potentially becomes less relevant. The world of bits increasingly eclipses the world of atoms in governance velocity and scope. What matters long-term are frameworks that keep humans meaningfully in the loop with appropriate input rather than either total control or complete exclusion.

sub_fields.title: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.description: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.answer:
The most fundamental impact sovereigns.institute creates for the Cardano ecosystem emerges from solving a problem that has constrained every distributed technological system attempting genuine decentralization: how do you protect individual contributors from legal vulnerability while enabling multidisciplinary expertise to shape governance frameworks that automated systems will eventually inherit and operate within? Right now, people building valuable infrastructure or contributing specialized knowledge to ecosystem development remain personally exposed to legal action without any institutional backing defending them. 



This protection gap means the ecosystem systematically loses contributors who cannot afford the risk, particularly those from jurisdictions where legal systems prove less predictable or more expensive to navigate. By creating organizational infrastructure that provides genuine legal protection while integrating expertise across disciplines that typically remain separated, sovereigns.institute enables participation from people who currently must remain on the sidelines despite having knowledge the ecosystem desperately needs.



Consider what happens when healthcare practitioners, cultural anthropologists, legal scholars focused on indigenous rights, educators working with underserved populations, and disaster management specialists can work directly alongside cryptographers and distributed systems engineers within unified frameworks designed to keep humans meaningfully in the loop as automation advances. 



The governance schema emerging from this integration become technical foundations that all ecosystem participants can reference and build upon, creating shared vocabulary and architectural patterns that reduce fragmentation. 



When a developer in Buenos Aires, a community organizer in Lagos, and a rural municipality official in Hokkaido can all work with the same governance frameworks because those frameworks were designed through genuinely international participatory processes accounting for subject-object-verb linguistic structures and cultural context from inception rather than as afterthoughts, the ecosystem gains coordination capabilities that homogeneous governance structures simply cannot provide.





The international workshop approach with deep engagement across Central Saint Martins, University of the Arts London, Tokyo University of the Arts, and Institute of Science Tokyo creates something rarely seen in technological ecosystems: patient collaborative development where variables discovered through deliberation settle into understood constants before commitments solidify into inflexible structures. 



This inverted approach where community designs governance schema before any legal entity forms prevents the pattern that constrained prior organizational attempts where entities formed quickly then struggled endlessly to become what communities actually needed. 



The educational content produced in eight languages with genuine cultural adaptation rather than superficial translation means that constitutional representatives from fifty-one countries can engage with governance concepts in ways that make sense within their own cultural contexts rather than forcing adoption of foreign conceptual frameworks that never quite fit local realities.





The regulatory landscape exploration coordinated with build.foundation technical security validation creates unprecedented value for the entire ecosystem by establishing pathways for demonstrating schema-governed compliance while genuinely preserving privacy. 



When sovereigns.institute engages with UK regulatory sandboxes spanning financial services, data protection, healthcare innovation, food safety, energy systems, transportation, and legal service provision while maintaining protective commitments rather than compromising them for regulatory approval, the entire ecosystem benefits from proven approaches to institutional engagement. This matters enormously because regulatory relationships either enable or constrain every subsequent development initiative, and having organizational infrastructure that can navigate these relationships while maintaining technical and ethical integrity provides public good benefits extending far beyond immediate project scope.





The Donor-Advised Fund innovation combined with Alternative Business Structure multidisciplinary expertise creates mechanisms for evaluating and recognizing heterogeneous contributions that monetary systems fundamentally cannot capture. When an elderly resident's deep knowledge of traditional agricultural practices, a remote worker's technical skills, a municipality's equipment inventory, and external financial support can all contribute meaningfully through frameworks recognizing their distinct value forms appropriately, the ecosystem gains ability to coordinate resources that current architectures systematically exclude or undervalue. 



This becomes critical as automation transforms economic structures because maintaining human participation in governance requires recognizing value forms beyond simple monetary equivalents.

The applied prototyping using Japanese public data for disaster management and rural revitalization demonstrates that governance frameworks developed through this work enable real-world coordination under genuine pressure rather than only functioning in theoretical contexts. When earthquakes, tsunamis, typhoons, or infrastructure failures occur, schema-governed coordination that keeps humans meaningfully in the loop while enabling automated systems to operate reliably could literally save lives. 



The rural revitalization applications addressing depopulation, aging demographics, agricultural sustainability, and cultural preservation show how governance frameworks can help communities maintain vitality as economic structures transform. These concrete demonstrations attract attention from institutions and populations that speculative use cases never reach, expanding the ecosystem's relevance beyond early adopter communities into populations facing urgent challenges requiring coordination at scale.





Perhaps most importantly, sovereigns.institute establishes pattern for genuine community ownership where organizational forms serve as temporary scaffolding enabling emergence of something more fundamental rather than becoming ends in themselves. The synthesis documenting how governance insights shaped build.foundation technical decisions and how technical constraints influenced organizational design throughout twelve-month collaboration provides the entire ecosystem with concrete examples of co-evolution between human governance and technical infrastructure rather than abstract assertions of alignment. This demonstrates possibility for escaped institutional forms where what persists beyond organizational containers are the governance frameworks themselves, operating at velocity and granularity automation demands while keeping humans meaningfully involved across diverse cultural and professional perspectives.

**Preface: Important Note on ADA Price Collapse **



_When Fund 15 budget thresholds and category limits were being conceived and set \(September–early October 2025\), ADA was trading at approximately £0\.60 GBP and ¥120 JPY per ₳1\. All budgeting and scoping for this proposal \(both the original milestone amounts and the detailed line items below\) were prepared in good faith using those exchange rates\._



_In the roughly one to two months since then — from when the Fund 15 budget and thresholds were being set — ADA has halved to around £0\.30 GBP and ¥60 \(as of 27 November 2025\)\. This means the fixed\-ADA budget presented here now delivers only about half the originally assumed fiat purchasing power for salaries, international travel \(London & Tokyo\), venue costs, regulatory work, and development hours\._





_The proposer remains fully committed to delivering every promised milestone and output, but voters should understand that the requested ADA amount now represents approximately double the real\-world cost that was assumed when Fund 15 rules and expectations were established\._



Milestone 1

(Month 4, ₳25,321):

Workshop facilitation & personnel (₳10,000),

venue & travel expenses (₳6,000),

design & schema development (₳5,000),

community platform setup (₳3,321),

documentation & attribution (₳1,000).

(Month 8, ₳15,000):

Prototyping & validation (₳5,000),

educational & cultural adaptation (₳4,000),
